abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though institutional
            development impacts were only modest. Following are some
            lessons learned from the project experience. Taking into
            account the project's expected, and improved delivery
            of services, as well as the inherent reforms it entails,
            such reforms must be accompanied by adequate Government
            resources to support them, that is funding for the agreed
            requirements under the legislation (Water and Sanitation
            Act, 1997), redundancy payments, and working capital, while
            the consequences of a reform agenda on the Government budget
            must be clearly identified. Regarding civil works, the
            choice of expenditure was for items with heavy foreign
            exchange content, with the expectation that the public
            sector would undertake less capital intensive works, such as
            repair and expansion to the distribution system. This
            technology choice is reflected in the negative Net Present
            Value (NPV), where heavy capital costs for rehabilitation,
            are not set against increased numbers of consumers, showing
            instead consistent low returns, since by and large, benefits
            in water supply systems come from expanding the
            distribution, and selling more water. But, the public sector
            did not choose to invest in the expansion of the
            distribution system, actually, the number of consumers did
            not increase dramatically. With respect to water borne
            disease and cholera, the lack of focus on sanitation may
            have lowered the effectiveness regarding disease control,
            but a health component that would include hygiene education,
            and thus achieved these objectives, may not be best placed
            in a water rehabilitation project.
